text:
Hudson Street, north across Reade Street. At the right is West Broadway. The several low structures there are at the triangular apex formed by the convergence of these two thoroughfares. The writer believes that the photographer is standing on the "El" platform station at Chambers Street. The wooded area in the left center is the small Duane Park. Beyond appears the American Express Building at the S.W. corner of Jay Street. The opposite corner (with canopy) will become the site of the House of Relief of the New York Hospital and which later housed the present Marine Hospital.

About 1870's

H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

(1) At the convergence of Hudson Street (left) and West Broadway (right), looking northward from Reade Street. The 6-story building at the apex bears Nos. 114-116 Reade Street, 24 Hudson Street and 110-116 West Broadway. Also shown is the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line on the latter Street. July 2, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, at a later date, showing the Western Union Building on Thomas Street, between Hudson Street and West Broadway (former site of the R.C. Williams warehouses). February 11, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, Hudson Street and West Broadway at point of intersection. May 4, 1941.
P.L. Sperr,

December 25, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
